title: Reference Matter
description: Test your knowledge of footnotes, citations, bibliographies, indexes, and reference formatting.

questions.stem: Where should footnote numbers appear in relation to punctuation?

options.label: Only at the end of sentences

questions.rationale: Footnote numbers should appear after punctuation marks to maintain proper text flow.

questions.stem: What does 'Ibid.' mean in footnotes?

options.label: The same author as previous note
The same source as immediately preceding note

questions.rationale: 'Ibid.' (ibidem) means 'in the same place' and refers to the immediately preceding citation.

questions.stem: For subsequent references to the same work, use a ________ version of the title rather than 'op. cit.'
questions.rationale: Modern practice favors shortened titles over the Latin 'op. cit.' for clarity.

questions.stem: Find the error in this footnote:
questions.text: ¹Smith, John. Canadian Policy Analysis. Ottawa: Government Publishing, 2023. p. 45.

errors.reason: Page numbers in footnotes don't need 'p.' prefix

questions.rationale: Book titles should be italicized, and page numbers don't need 'p.' in footnotes.

questions.stem: How should footnotes be spaced on the page?

options.label: Double spaced like the main text

questions.rationale: Footnotes should be single spaced within each note to save space while maintaining readability.

questions.stem: How should bibliography entries be arranged?
questions.rationale: Bibliography entries are arranged alphabetically by author's last name or by title if no author.

questions.stem: Find the formatting error in this bibliography entry:
questions.text: Brown, Michael. Fiscal Policy Trends. Canadian Public Administration 67, no. 2 (2023): 145-162.

errors.reason: Article titles should be in quotation marks

questions.rationale: Article titles use quotation marks while journal titles are italicized.

questions.stem: Match the source type with its bibliography format:

pairs.right: Author. "Title." Journal Volume, no. Issue (Year): pages.

questions.rationale: Different source types require different bibliography formats.

questions.stem: How should entries with no author be alphabetized in a bibliography?

options.label: At the end of the bibliography

questions.rationale: Sources with no author are alphabetized by title, ignoring initial articles.

questions.stem: Bibliography entries should use ________ indent formatting.
questions.rationale: Hanging indent (first line flush left, subsequent lines indented) is standard for bibliographies.

questions.stem: When must you cite a source?

options.label: For direct quotations, paraphrased ideas, and statistical data
Only when the source requests it

questions.rationale: Citations are required for direct quotations, paraphrased ideas, statistical data, specific facts, and expert opinions.

questions.stem: Complete this APA-style in-text citation: The study found significant improvements ________, demonstrating policy effectiveness.
questions.rationale: APA style uses (Author, Year, p. Page) format for in-text citations with page numbers.

questions.stem: Which citation system uses numbers in square brackets?
questions.rationale: The numbered system uses numbers in square brackets [1] or parentheses (1) for citations.

questions.stem: Find the error in this citation:
questions.text: Recent policy changes have improved efficiency Wilson, 2023.

errors.reason: Citation should be enclosed in parentheses

questions.rationale: In-text citations should be properly formatted within parentheses.

questions.stem: What information must be included when citing a direct quotation?
questions.rationale: Direct quotations require complete citation information including specific page numbers.

questions.stem: What is the primary purpose of an index?

options.label: To list all words in a document
To provide an alphabetical guide to significant content
To replace the table of contents

questions.rationale: An index provides alphabetical access to significant names, places, and subjects in a document.

questions.stem: How should personal names be listed in an index?
questions.rationale: Personal names are indexed by surname: 'Smith, John' not 'John Smith.'

questions.stem: Find the formatting error in this index entry:
questions.rationale: Index subentries must be properly indented to show hierarchy.

questions.stem: For page ranges in an index, use ________ to connect the numbers.
questions.rationale: Page ranges use hyphens or en dashes: '45-47' not '45 to 47.'

questions.stem: What type of cross-reference directs readers from a non-preferred term?
questions.rationale: 'See' references direct from non-preferred terms to preferred terms.

questions.stem: What essential element should be included for all online sources?
questions.rationale: Complete URLs are essential for readers to locate online sources.

questions.stem: For online sources that may change, include the ________ date when you accessed the information.
questions.rationale: Access or retrieval dates help verify the version of online content used.

questions.stem: Find the missing element in this electronic source citation:
questions.text: Johnson, Mary. "New Economic Policies Announced." CBC News. https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/economic-policies.
questions.rationale: Electronic sources need publication dates when available.

questions.stem: What is a DOI in academic citations?
questions.rationale: DOI (Digital Object Identifier) provides a permanent link to academic sources.

questions.stem: How should PDF documents be identified in citations?
questions.rationale: PDF documents should be identified as 'PDF file' to clarify the format.

questions.stem: How should federal statutes be cited?
questions.rationale: Federal statutes require title, year, and chapter number for proper identification.

questions.stem: Court cases should include the case name, ________, court, and year.
questions.rationale: Legal citations must include the official citation to locate the case in law reports.

questions.stem: Find the error in this legal citation:

errors.reason: Year should be in square brackets for court citation format

questions.rationale: Supreme Court citations use square brackets around the year.

questions.stem: What information is essential for citing regulations?
questions.rationale: Regulations require both title and regulation number for proper citation.

questions.stem: Why is it important to verify the current status of cited laws?

options.label: To ensure they haven't been repealed or amended

questions.rationale: Laws can be repealed, amended, or struck down, so current status must be verified.

questions.stem: How many levels of entries should an index typically have?

options.label: Three levels maximum for most indexes

questions.rationale: Most indexes work best with main entries, subentries, and occasional sub-subentries (3 levels).

questions.stem: Use '________ also' references to guide readers to related topics.
questions.rationale: 'See also' references connect related topics and improve index navigation.

questions.stem: How should significant discussions be marked in an index?
questions.rationale: Bold page numbers indicate where topics receive significant discussion.

questions.stem: Find the cross-reference error:
questions.text:
Budget. See also Fiscal policy; Government spending
Fiscal policy, 23, 45-47
Government spending, 89-91

errors.reason: Should cross-reference to Budget since it's mentioned in Budget's 'See also'

questions.rationale: Cross-references should be reciprocal when appropriate.

questions.stem: What should be checked during index quality control?
questions.rationale: Quality control must verify alphabetical order, page number accuracy, and cross-reference validity.
